I mean... it's just Minesweeper, but better.
I love to unwind with a simple puzzle game, slowly revealing the board until it's finally solved. Minesweeper is a basic formula with a few tricks to keep it interesting, and that's all it needs to be almost endlessly entertaining. Nonetheless, it has one main issue--and unfortunately, it is the natural result of its most important asset. That issue is the random puzzle generation, which permits countless levels, including the ones that cannot be solved without the occasional random guess. Any amount of reliance on luck in a logic puzzle is frustrating, because it can make all your hard work irrelevant. 
This is why Hexceed is an improvement on the Minesweeper formula. Every level in this game is hand-crafted to be solvable, no matter how difficult. The tradeoff is a limit to the amount of levels in the game, but.. trust me, it's nothing to worry about. Here, let's have a quick math intermission...
I currently have 30.6 hours on record. I have completed 249 levels. That's an average of 7.23 minutes per level-- most likely skewed to be lower since I played every one of the tutorial levels (even though they were completely optional). Without purchasing any of the level packs, you are provided a total of 435 free levels (plus 36 bonus levels if you check out their social medias), or somewhere around 65 hours of free content depending on various factors.
This does much to establish Hexceed as a largely superior version of Minesweeper, but there's still some more things worth mentioning. As a reminder, this game is not identical to Minesweeper-- the puzzles may be similar in structure, but they are still completely unique to this game. There are special tiles and special tricks, so it provides a fresh experience to anyone who might have felt Minesweeper was getting a bit stale. Since the levels are hand-crafted, this also results in some really uniquely designed levels that creatively use all these unique tiles. And to top it all off, they added toggles for a hardcore mode, a hint feature, and a tile range highlighter, so that the difficulty level can be customized. All of this adds up to quite a lot for a completely free experience; honestly, I consider the inclusion of level packs as more of a feature that allows me to support the creators.

[b]How hard is it:[/b] Easy to moderate, but the overall difficulty is up to you. By default the game is very helpful and forgiving, making the wrong move simply highlights your mistake and rolls back a few tiles, but to completely master a level pack you have to enable hardcore mode where a single mistake resets the whole level, not use the highlighter, not use hints, and finish the entire pack in one sitting. Still, even with all these restrictions, the vast majority of the levels are straightforward, most of the time you just use one or two rules to figure out the next move.

[b]How long is it:[/b] 20+ packs of around 100-200 levels each, with new ones being added a few times per year. [b]Level design:[/b] Good. Each level requires only logic, no guessing, many are very interesting, yet over thousands of levels they are sure to get repetitive. Thankfully, new mechanics being added every few packs add variety.

This is an okay game to zen out, and a very disappointing game if you're looking for a logical challenge.  It's free and I gladly spent a dozen hours just zoning out on it while binging a podcast in the other tab.  But just putting it out there that what you're getting for your zero dollars is a very large package of trivial by-the-motions puzzles that will probably not stretch your brainpan.

The game is basically just an expansion of Hexcells.  Mechanically, it had every right to be a direct improvement.  There's a lot of great usability options in viewing clue areas, resetting the puzzle or not if you mess up, and generally just customizing the experience well.  The additional mechanics lend themselves to the potential for very clever level design, with plenty of ways to control how you uncover the board, gate your progress, or suddenly reveal loose threads on faraway sections.

But unfortunately the actual levels rarely use them well.  In short, there's typically an extreme overabundance of clues on the board, far more than are necessary to solve things.  When you uncover a green ring or blue triangle area clue, it's about 50/50 if you'll even have to acknowledge its existence at all.  A good deal of the walls between cells don't actually constrain the logic because most of the time you approach them from completed directions that immediately uncover [i]both sides of the wall at once,[/i] and often just blow right past it with a long string of zero-cells that uncover a quarter of the map without having to apply any thought at all.  Red line and multiline clues are used only in the most basic way possible, and are never used to intersect or have any sort of consequences to each other.  Every once in a while you see a level with a decent use of the board's geometry where these clues are used to navigate split-off sections and bounce around a bit.  But most feel like someone drew a basic board shape, randomly populated it by machine, and then algorithmically verified solvability.   In any given level probably a third to half of its features more complicated than basic number cells are totally superfluous and neither assist nor impede the logical path of least resistance in any way; you'll run into several clues or walls every level and ask "why do you even exist?".  It really, really begged for good curated level design and it just got totally phoned in.

This is all exemplified by the Milestone levels, which usually present a hilariously massive board that looks like it should be a labyrinthine trail of logic navigating between different interconnected sections, but in practice you just steamroll through it almost entirely on the most face-value clues.  What should have been a culmination of design and mechanics usage instead just turns into shoveling a very large pile of the exact same trivial stuff to click through.

It's incredibly disappointing and feels like such a cosmic waste.

Tl;Dr Minesweeper, but with work put it to take the fun out of it. 
(played the tutorial campaign, couldn't be bothered to play any more of it)

First of all, there's the switch from squares to hexagons, and despite what CGP Grey may have you believe, hexagons aren't always best, because in minesweeper it removes some of the logical deductions you can make with squares.

Next, there's the designed levels instead of randomly generated ones, and although that might seem like a good thing, it results in it feeling like there's a set out path you need to follow as intended by the level designer, which really makes the game less interesting.

Then there's new types of clues, which can actually be fun, but in many cases I've found that their use was either redundant (i.e. it was just as easy, if not easier, to figure out the same thing using regular clues) or gimmicky (e.g. it was just use to reveal the start of a new section of the map, which just as well could've been smaller individual maps; there was even a point where they added the symbol of a mechanic to all sides even though trough walls blocking things, it would've provided exactly the same clue as if it was the same number but using a regular clue)

There's also the way the game handles wrong clicks, you're allowed a wrong click, but another wrong click shortly after rewinds your progress a bit (but after a couple of right moves, you're out of the danger zone again and can make another mistake at no cost); I suppose that's intended to be more forgiving to mistakes whilst still punishing completely random guessing, but it doesn't work well.

"This is Minesweeper!" - Sort of, but there's never a need to guess.  You will always have a valid move.

"This is Hexcells!" - This is closer to the truth, but still not quite accurate.

Hexceed is a Minesweeper/Hexcells-like puzzle game, that features an few interesting mechanic changes, and generally benefits from them.

First of all, one of the most notable things to me is that Hexceed has figured out how to handle guessing correctly.  Under Hexcells, if you guess a tile and get it wrong, there's very little cost to you.  You have an unlimited number of guesses, and in any event, once you guess wrong, you know the solution to that cell.  In Hexceed, incorrect guesses start costing you. You get a few free, but get too many, and it will start resetting parts of the puzzle, causing you to have to go back and re-figure those tiles.  It's VERY effective, and neatly solves a problem I've always had with Hexcells.

There are a few new clue-types, like multi-direction counts, and sweeps.  The former is one or more little arrows that point off in the six directions.  The number of mines in each of the directions totals up to the number in the cell.  This, I don't think, was well explained.  Sweeps show the number of mines in a triangular sector pointing out from the cell. Lastly, there's a 'wall' feature that will break off a rule.  

These new clues can be tough to get the hang of, and the game doesn't have the line- and section- marker feature that Hexcells has.  Instead, it has a single highlighter tool that will show you all the tiles that are impacted by a single clue.  That's probably the most effective teacher, so learn how to use it quickly.

That's also sort of the problem, though.  The game is constantly watching you and counting everything you do, and while it won't yell at you for using the highlighter, it will KNOW.  You aren't told until you've completed the quite long and intricate tutorial level that it has noticed that you're not perfect.

The configuration options on the game are broad and varied, allowing this game to be the right game for a broad range of people.  I think if you enjoyed Hexcells, then you will enjoy this.  If you're new to this style of game, this might not be the best place to start.  There's almost no text and nearly zero explanations of how to get going.  There's a 'clue' button, but I honestly haven't yet seen how it works.  I think the intro in Hexcells was much more gentle.

But I'm actually quite curious to hear if you find differently.  The game's tutorial levels are VERY well designed, I'm just not sure if it is enough to get started from first principles.  Regardless, it's currently free-to-play, and I've put two hours into it and have yet to be hit with an upsell.  I'm not sure you can go wrong with this one.

To start things off, this is a ripoff of Hexcells but instead of including a level generator with the game like Hexcells Infinite did, this game packages them up into paid DLC. That being said, there are a few things that set this game apart from Hexcells.

Matthew Brown has proven himself a skilled puzzle designer but ToastieLabs seems to have copied the puzzle concept without a real understanding of what makes a good puzzle. One telltale sign that these are simply randomly generated is the fact that puzzles will oftentimes have many clues which are completely useless; natural progression of the level will lead you to uncover all the hexes they could possibly help with and you'll never even use them. This was never the case with Hexcells; every labeled clue was an important step in the solution process. I'm not a big believer in hand-holding (especially for puzzle games) but I don't think it's too much to ask that the game at least tell you the objective and give some hint text explaining the controls (e.g. that you can hold down on a cell to see which cells are affected by the clue).
